derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English: from Old Norse mȳrr, of Germanic origin; related to moss

entry.def: You can refer to an unpleasant or difficult situation as a mire of some kind.

example.ex: ...the muck and mire of sewers and farm- yards.
example.tran: 下水道和农家庭院的污垢和烂泥

means.word_mean: 1. a soft wet area of low-lying land that sinks underfoot

sentences.sentence: "Our people should not be mired in the past"

means.word_mean: 2. cause to get stuck as if in a mire;

sentences.sentence: "The car bogged down in the sand"

means.word_mean: 4. soil with mud, muck, or mire;

sentences.sentence: "The child mucked up his shirt while playing ball in the garden"
